title: Race marshal airlifted to hospital after motocross bike lands on him
text:
Witnesses said the steward was hit by a bike that landed on his head during a practice race (Picture: Getty)

A beach motocross event had to be halted after a bike landed on top of a race steward.

The steward was hit by one of the motorbikes during a practice run on Weymouth Beach, Dorset, at around 12.30pm today – around half an hour after the event began.

Pictures from the scene showed a man in a fluorescent yellow vest lying on the sand next to the race course.

An air ambulance was called to the beach before the seriously injured steward was flown to Southampton Hospital.

Witnesses said the man was hit on the head and described seeing him being taken into the helicopter on a stretcher.

A heavy police presence was seen in the area, those attending said.

The man was airlifted to Southampton Hospital with serious injuries (Picture: Getty)

The annual Weymouth Beach Motocross event was temporarily halted before races began again at 3pm (Picture: Getty)

The event was temporarily stopped but races began again at around 3pm, the Dorset Echo reports.

More than 300 riders were expected to take part in this year’s beach race, which went ahead despite forecasts of rain.

Riders include experts who have won championships in the UK and abroad.

The event first started in in 1984 and has grown to be the biggest amateur race of its kind in the UK.
